If there were nothing before the dead except the terror of that blowing (of the Trumpet), it would be worthy of being feared, for it is a blowing and a cry by which those in the heavens and the earth are struck unconscious, meaning they die by it except whom Allah wills, and that is some of the angels. And for that reason, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'How can I enjoy comfort when the possessor of the Trumpet has taken the horn into his mouth, lowered his forehead, and inclined his ear, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow?' [144] Muqatil said: The Trumpet (As-Sur) is the horn, and that is because Israfil (upon him be peace) has placed his mouth on the horn like the form of a trumpet, and the circle of the horn's head is like the expanse of the heavens and the earth, and he is fixing his gaze toward the Throne, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow the first blowing. And when he blows, those in the heavens and the earth are struck unconscious, meaning every living creature dies from the intensity of the terror except whom Allah wills, and that is Jibril, Mika'il, Israfil, and the Angel of Death (Malak al-Mawt). Then the Angel of Death is commanded to take the spirit (Ruh) of Jibril, then the spirit (Ruh) of Mika'il, then the spirit (Ruh) of Israfil, then the Angel of Death is commanded and he dies. Then the creation remains after the first blowing in the Intermediate State (Al-Barzakh) for forty years. Then Allah the Exalted revives Israfil and commands him to blow the second blowing, and that is His saying, the Exalted: 'Then it will be blown into it another time, and behold, they are standing, looking.' [Quran 39:68] On their feet, looking at the Resurrection. And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'When I was sent, I was sent to the possessor of the Trumpet, and he inclined it to his mouth, and advanced one foot and delayed another, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow. Indeed, fear the blowing!' [145] So reflect upon the creation and their humiliation, their breaking, and their submission at the time of being raised up, out of fear of this unconsciousness and waiting for it.

This is because in public display there is a third danger besides reminding of favor (Al-Mann) and showing off (Riya'), which is exposing the cover of the poor person. For perhaps he is harmed by being seen in the image of the needy. So whoever makes the request public is the one who exposed his own cover. Therefore, one should not be cautious of this meaning in his public display, and it is like exposing immorality upon one who concealed it, for that is prohibited, and spying into it and habitual mention of it is forbidden. As for whoever exposes it, establishing the punishment upon him is publicizing, but he is the cause in it. And with a meaning like this, the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'Whoever casts off the garment of modesty (Al-Haya'), then there is no backbiting for him.' And Allah the Exalted has said: 'And spend from what We have provided for you secretly and publicly' (Quran 13:22). He encouraged to public display also because of the benefit of encouragement in it. So let the servant (Al-'Abd) be precise in contemplation in weighing this benefit against the danger that is in it, for that differs according to circumstances and persons. Indeed, public announcement in some circumstances for some persons may be better. And whoever knows the benefits and dangers and does not look with the eye of desire (Al-Shahwah), the most appropriate and fitting for every situation becomes clear to him.

We say: The true spiritual state (Wajd) is what arises from excessive love (Hubb) of Allah the Exalted and the sincerity of one's intention (Iradah) and longing (Shawq) for meeting Him, and that is also stirred by hearing the Quran. And Allah the Exalted has said: 'Indeed, the believers are those whose Hearts (Qulub) tremble when Allah is mentioned.' And He the Exalted said: 'If We had sent down this Quran upon a mountain, you would have seen it humbled, split asunder from the fear (Khashyah) of Allah.' What indicates this from transmission is the saying of the entire community: 'What He wills is, and what He does not will is not,' and the saying of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic: 'If Allah had willed, He would have guided all people together' (Quran 13:31), and His saying, exalted be He: 'And if We had willed, We could have given every soul its guidance' (Quran 32:13).
